questions.question: What does the componentDidMount() method do in React?
choices: It sends data to the server
It initializes the component after it is mounted
It initializes the component before it is mounted
It triggers an update to the component when it is mounted
questions.answer: It initializes the component after it is mounted

questions.question: What is the difference between a PureComponent and a Component in React?
choices: PureComponents have immutable data and Components have mutable data
PureComponents check for shallow changes in props and state
Components check for deep changes in props and state
questions.answer: PureComponents check for shallow changes in props and state

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'higher order component' concept in React?
choices: It allows components to be used in multiple contexts
It allows components to be reused across applications
It allows components to be nested within other components
It allows components to communicate with each other
questions.answer: It allows components to be reused across applications

questions.question: What is a ref in React?
choices: A callback that is triggered when a component is mounted/unmounted
A callback that is triggered when a component's state changes
A reference to a particular element/component in the DOM
A flag that indicates whether a component has been mounted or unmounted
questions.answer: A reference to a particular element/component in the DOM

questions.question: What is the difference between a compiler and an interpreter?

questions.answer: A compiler translates code into a machine language while an interpreter runs code at the same time it is translated

questions.question: What are libraries?

questions.question: What is the difference between a programming language and a scripting language?

A programming language is written in text while a scripting language is written in binary

A set of rules for writing a program

questions.question: What is an operating system?
choices: A software program that manages the computer's hardware and software resources

questions.question: What is the difference between a source code and an object code?

A source code is a type of data type while an object code is a type of variable
A source code is a type of variable while an object code is a type of data type
questions.answer: A source code is the code that a programmer writes while an object code is the code that is generated from the source code after compilation

questions.question: What is the main difference between a web application and a desktop application?
choices: Web applications run in a web browser while desktop applications run on a computer's operating system
